Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: New Directions in Optical-Instrument-Driven Aeronomy at Arecibo Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will use the enhanced instrument cluster at Arecibo Observatory (AO) to gain new insight into the complex nature of the space-atmosphere interaction region (SAIR). The new High Frequency (HF) heating facility with the ISR (Incoherent Scatter Radar) and other instruments provides a unique opportunity to study heating-related aeronomic and plasma physics problems. This includes the rapidly-imaged observation of airglow at 557.7 nm, 630.0 nm and 427.8 nm during ionospheric "heating" campaigns to understand the role of HF-heating in generating plasma bubbles, or modulating them if already present, and to understand the role of secondary suprathermal electrons in producing airglow at different wavelengths. This research will also yield insight to the heating process, including locating ionospheric "hot-spots", yielding details of the electron collision process, elucidating the role of Langmuir and ion-acoustic waves in the strongly heated regions, and study of heating effects in Sporadic E. The latter study will include Ca+ metal-lidar observations as further defined by 555.7 nm imaging as well as ISR and HF radar results. HF heating of the ionosphere offers a unique opportunity to investigate the plasma heating process and its effects on the neutrals in a controlled (experimental) fashion. Outside of the heating campaigns, a database of 630 nm all-sky camera images from other locations will be assembled collaboratively to investigate the global context of the omnipresent ~1 hr period ionospheric waves, and associated dynamics, first identified with the AO ISR. This work will utilize other AO instruments, including the resonance and Rayleigh lidars, to investigate the role of wave coupling from lower atmospheric regions. Also, a proposed new CCD camera will allow high speed imaging to better understand HF heating effects and linking optical and radar meteors to study meteoroid aeronomy. The response of the SAIR to sudden changes in the environment caused by heating will be explored with the collaborative use of multiple instruments, thus informing numerous geophysical research areas. The multidisciplinary nature of this work will help to establish collaborations with plasma physicists, modelers, and space weather scientists. It will also advance the AO cluster capabilities with the addition of a User-Owned, Public Access (UOPA) high frame rate CCD to the current imager and help in establishing international collaborations. Students representing minorities from local universities in Puerto Rico will be encouraged to participate in observations and data analysis. They will be involved in the improvements of the optical systems including training on AO instrumentation and the application of these instruments to study aeronomy of the SAIR.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Different metals (sodium, potassium, iron, calcium, magnesium etc) and their ions are deposited through the meteor input in the Mesosphere and the Lower Thermosphere (MLT) region of the Earth's atmosphere. Neutrals and their ions act as tracers to investigate the so-called 'Ignosphere' by using lidars and radars.  Lasers are tuned to the resonance wavelength of the metal under investigation, and the backscattered signal is analyzed for inferring dynamics and energetics of the MLT region. Atmospheric gravity waves (buoyancy waves) perturb the medium through which they propagate, and hence induce variations in the metallic layer. Additionally, simultaneous observations of ions and neutrals allow us to validate chemistry models. Hence, co-located instruments like lidars and Incoherent scatter radar (as at the Arecibo Observatory, AO) offer excellent opportunity to investigate different regions of the ionosphere along with atmosphere-ionosphere interactions.

The NSF grant allowed the investigators to upgrade several instruments relevant for upper atmospheric investigations. The new developments include upgrade of one of the lidar receivers, which was the part of multi-metal lidar system. This instrument is based on state of the art commercial Nd:YAG laser that pumps a dye laser at a repetition rate of 50 Hz. The second harmonic from YAG at 532 nm can either be used for Rayleigh temperatures or is used for pumping the dye laser. The output from the latter at 589 nm is the resonance wavelength of neutral sodium (Na), and hence it is used for monitoring its concentration. The upgrades allowed the replacement of Photo-Multiplier Tube (PMT) with a high quantum efficiency tube along with an addition of UV PMT tube for detection of photons at 393 nm, resonance wavelength of calcium ions (Ca+). It is worth mentioning that Ca+ are the only metal ions that can be observed using ground based systems, since all other major metallic ions (Mg+, Fe+) have resonance wavelengths in deep UV, and are highly attenuated by the atmospheric ozone. These resulted in high-resolution data sets with a temporal resolution as low as 5 seconds and a range resolution of 75 m. These efforts led to the following new innovative scientific results:

(1) High-resolution Na data revealed multiple billows that are indicators of neutral instabilities in the atmosphere.

(2) Sporadic E is a phenomenon that refers to very thin layers of ionization in the E region of the ionosphere. Wind shears in the horizontal winds occurring in the vertical direction lead to the accumulation of metal ions at the null points. The high range resolution allowed for the detection of Ca+ ions in very narrow altitude ranges. This suggested that reversal in the winds could occur within altitudes regions < 150 m.

(3) The improvement in the signal to noise ratio as a result of new upgrades allowed the first direct detection of metal ions in the F-region valley during pre-dawn hours. Three nights of simultaneous observations (28 - 30 Nov 2016) of Ca+ and Ne using a resonance lidar and Incoherent scatter radar revealed many interesting aspects. These coordinated measurements showed occurrence of Ca+ at the edge of the Intermediate Descending Layers between 150 - 180 km altitude regions.

(4)  Another intriguing result is the absence of Ca+ ion with in the descending layers during pre-midnight hours on all the three nights.

(5) Very strong sporadic E was observed on 30 Nov 2016 with Ca+ values as high as 600 ions/cm-3. This night displayed uplift of the entire E region after midnight and its eventual merging with the ionospheric F region descending layers. This presents an excellent example of the coupling of the E and F region, which appears to result from electrodynamics since the metal neutral layers were not lifted upwards.

Additionally, the grant provided several opportunities for mentoring undergraduate students in STEM fields. The PI worked with many students (some representing under-represented groups) that were part of REU (Research Experience for Undergraduate) program at Arecibo Observatory. This allowed them to work on data analysis, and collect data getting 'hands-on' experience. Some of these students presented their work at AGU (American Geophysical Union) meeting.

The PI has access to the visitor center at Arecibo Observatory, where she presented the significance of scientific activities to the general public during an event 'Meet the Scientist'. This event is organized by the staff of the visitor center to increase general awareness about the research activities performed at AO to the students and other visitors from all walks of life.

In summary, the work and activities that were possible through this grant has provided new insights into ionosphere-atmosphere interactions. Future work need to focus on regular measurements of metallic calcium ions that act as proxy for major metallic ions.
